citeinfo.title: Salt marsh viability (regularly and irregularly flooded) by marsh complex in 2100 under a 1m sea level rise by 2100 scenario for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas.

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

pubinfo.pubplace: 205 N. Carizzo Street, Corpus Christi, TX, 78401, US

citeinfo.title: Informing conservation and resiliency planning using sea-level rise and storm-surge scenario impact estimates in Corpus Christi Bay

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

descript.abstract: This dataset shows the most and least viable salt marshes (irregularly flooded and regularly flooded) by 2006 marsh complex (polygons > 2500 sq. meters) in 2100 under a 1 meter SLR scenario, based on the amount of marsh remaining in the intitial 2006 footprint. Marsh viability was calculated by comparing the initial marsh footprint to that which is predicted to remain in the original marsh footprint by 2100. This was accomplished by calculating the percent change of marsh area within the initial marsh footprint to that which remians in 2100. The 5 classes shown (1= high viability and 5=Low viability) were classified based on a Natural Breaks classification which helps to show maximum differences in marsh viability per census block group and is a relative measure of viability within the project region. This dataset is based on results from the application of SLAMM.
descript.purpose: This file was created for The Nature Conservancy's Sea Level Rise Project for the northern Gulf of Mexico with funding from the Coastal Bend Bays and Estuary Program (CBBEP). The map represents the viability of salt marshes (regularly and irregularly flooded) by 2006 marsh complex, which were derived from predicted landcover maps of Corpus Christi Bay, Texas. This dataset shows predicted salt marsh viability in 2100 within the initial marsh footprint under a 1m SLR scenario by 2100. The landcover maps used for the study area were derived from Sea Level Rise Affecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) using the 1m of sea-level rise by 2100 scenario which predict how marshes might migrate inland due to increasing sea levels.

procstep.procdesc: TNC Conservation and Resiliency analyses were created from SLAMM and ADCIRC modeling outputs for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas (see reports at www.SLRportal.org)

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number indentifying the marsh polygons > 2500 sq. meters

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
Length in meters defining the features.
Area (sq. meters) defining the area of marsh footprint in 2006.
Area (sq. meters) of marsh remaining in 2100 within original 2006 marsh footprint (polygon)
Viability scores are calculated as percent change (0-100)of marsh remaining in 2100 within the intitial 2006 marsh footprint
